head.title: Metro Business; Board Is Reshuffled At Carver Bancorp

hedline.hl1: Metro Business; Board Is Reshuffled At Carver Bancorp

abstract.p: Carver Bancorp, largest black-run bank in country, reports loss of more than $1 million in 1999; reshuffles board; four members, including former Mayor David N Dinkins and chairman David R Jones, resign; new chairman is Frederick O Terrell (S)

block.p: The Carver Bancorp, the largest black-run bank in the country, announced late yesterday that it had lost more than $1 million in the last year, and that it had reshuffled its board.
Four board members resigned, including David N. Dinkins, the former mayor, and David R. Jones, the bank's chairman and president of the Community Service Society, a major city charity.
The Carver Bancorp, the largest black-run bank in the country, announced late yesterday that it had lost more than $1 million in the last year, and that it had reshuffled its board.
Four board members resigned, including David N. Dinkins, the former mayor, and David R. Jones, the bank's chairman and president of the Community Service Society, a major city charity.

Two businessmen with experience at large corporations are joining the board: Robert Holland, a former president of Ben & Jerry's, who is now chief executive of Workplace Integrators, a furniture dealership; and Strauss Zelnick, who is now the chief executive of B.M.G. Entertainment.
The new chairman of Carver is Frederick O. Terrell, the chief executive of Provender Capital, who became a director in January after his firm invested in the bank.

Carver, which lost almost $6 million before taxes in the 1999 fiscal year, had reported improved financial results this year. But it said yesterday that more than $400,000 of the $2 million in profits it reported as of year-end were the result of an ''incorrect accounting entry.''
Combined with a $2.6 million loss in the three months ended March, Carver reported a loss for the 2000 fiscal year of slightly more than $1 million.
